intro: Geanthus brevilabris, commonly known as the short-labiate geanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family, characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and have a rough texture, while its flowers are arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems. Geanthus brevilabris is often found in arid or semi-arid environments, making it well adapted to drought conditions.
